definitions.definition: immediately after the first and before any others:
examples: Is Carla her first or second child?

definitions.definition: the position in which a person finishes a race or competition if they finish immediately behind the winner:
examples: First prize is two weeks in Barbados and second prize is a weekend in Rome.

definitions.definition: Second is used to show that only one thing is better, bigger, etc. than the thing mentioned:
examples: St Petersburg is Russia's second (biggest/largest) city.
She is often described as a second Marilyn Monroe.

definitions.definition: happening only once out of every two possible times:
examples: We've decided to hold the conference every second year.

definitions.definition: after the first and before any others:
examples: Robertson won the race and Cameron was/came/finished second.

definitions.definition: used to introduce the second thing in a list of things you want to say or write:
examples: There are two good reasons why we can't do it. First, we can't afford it, and second, we don't have time.

definitions.definition: a short unit of time that is equal to a 60th of a minute:
examples: There are 60 seconds in a minute.

definitions.definition: a very short period of time:
examples: "Come on, hurry up!" "I'll just/only be a second - I need to close the window."
The second I saw him, I knew he was going to be a star.

definitions.definition: to make a formal statement of support for a suggestion made by someone else during a meeting so that there can be a discussion or vote:
examples: The motion was proposed by the club's chairwoman and seconded by the secretary.

definitions.definition: to send an employee to work somewhere else temporarily, either to increase the number of workers or to replace other workers, or to exchange experience or skills:
examples: During the dispute, many police officers were seconded from traffic duty to the prison service.
